entry.et: Middle English, from Old English tægel; akin to Old High German zagal tail, Middle Irish dúal lock of hair

def.dt: :the rear end or a process or prolongation of the rear end of the body of an animal
:something resembling an animal's tail in shape or position: as
:a luminous stream of particles, gases, or ions extending from a comet especially in the antisolar direction
:the rear part of an airplane consisting usually of horizontal and vertical stabilizing surfaces with attached control surfaces
:retinue
:tailcoat
:full evening dress for men
:buttocks butt
:sexual intercourse
:the back, last, lower, or inferior part of something
:tailing 1 usually used in plural
:the reverse of a coin usually used in plural tails, I win
:one (as a detective) who follows or keeps watch on someone
:the blank space at the bottom of a page
:a location immediately or not far behind had a posse on his tail
:to connect end to end
:to remove the tail of (an animal) :dock
:to remove the stem or bottom part of topping and tailing gooseberries
:to make or furnish with a tail
:to follow or be drawn behind like a tail
:to follow for purposes of surveillance
:to form or move in a straggling line
:to grow progressively smaller, fainter, or more scattered :abate usually used with off productivity is tailing off Tom Nicholson
:to swing or lie with the stern in a named direction used of a ship at anchor
:tag

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from tailler

def.dt: :entail 1a

entry.et: Middle English taille, from Anglo-French taylé, past participle of tailler to cut, limit tailor

def.dt: :limited as to tenure :entailed
:one of the coverts of the tail quills
:buttocks rump
:the hindmost end
:the concluding period the tail end of the session
:the terminal fin of a fish or cetacean
:fin 2b
:a European tussock moth (Euproctis chrysorrhoea) introduced in the United States and having larvae which feed on foliage and have hairs irritating to the skin
:slattern
:retail business conducted online via the World Wide Web
